posts.name: Adam Pullen
posts.cooked:
Hello teams,

I am contemplating how to mount a battery on our KOPâ€™s chassis. I want something similar to the discontinued AM14U Horizontal Battery Mount.

This battery tray mounts perfectly into the AM14U family of chassis. The bungee then secures batteries into the tray.Multiple mounting holes are available to mount to more than just the AM14U series chassis as well. Keep your battery secure and safe...

Could you share how your team mounts the battery to the KOPâ€™s Chassis?

Thanks in advance -Adam

link_counts.title: AM14U Family Horizontal Battery Mount Kit - AndyMark, Inc

posts.cooked:
WARING: I have not actually used the KOP chassis for actual competitions, and have limited experience with it in general. So generally a battery strap seems to work just fine. Essentially just bolt some polycarb into the robot as a base, and have some slots cut out for the strap. I would recomend other things to be placed around the place the battery actually sits to constrain itâ€™s movements further. IMG_20230316_222240_036 1920Ã—2400 520 KB Battery would go where the transmitter currently rests. This is subotimal positioning for actual robots, and not the lack of constraining blocks. The constraining blocks would be relatively easy to mount, just use wood or spare metal and bolt through it with some washers, sort of like this: 20230112_182716 1920Ã—2560 906 KB While neither of these show the KOP chassis, the principles are relatively easy to apply to other chassis.

IMG_20230316_222240_036 1920Ã—2400 520 KB

IMG_20230316_222240_036 1920Ã—2400 520 KB

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Agreed, 1" aluminum angle works well here too (same concept as bot with purple noodle bumpers) if you need to create a little more space for something else.

posts.name: Mentor | 9047
posts.cooked: What material is used in the base of the chassis? With holes.
The first picture I think is polycarb. The second I think is MDF. That was just a test chassis.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked: 1293 has used the stock mount in the box since 2019.  We tend to find a way to design around it instead of worrying about engineering a new one.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Going back to OP, the current AM14 outside plates have essentially the same construction as the horizontal battery holder.  According to the drawings, the flat plane is 0.625" from the center of the hole.  Putting two of these in holes 8.5" apart in the end plate will leave you 7.25" gap.  The batteries are nominally 7.1", so youâ€™ll likely want a bit of padding in there.  The other pieces of the horizontal holder are a flat bar and a way to secure the bungee; shouldnâ€™t be difficult.

Thanks for everyones input! If anyone else needs a horizontal battery mount, I recommend using aluminum angle as Skyehawk mentioned. Keep it simple and make sure the battery is secure and easy to swap.
